Dear Mr. Edgar:
Report for the above referenced facility completed on August 13, 2018 and September 4,
2018. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted
that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MSA and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
One of five new employee records reviewed showed one of the
employee’s three references did not contain a date or the name
of the person taking the reference. It could not be ascertained
whether the reference was received before the employee’s
11/8/17 date of hire.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian
province, or other country where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state
police records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or
other country law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
Two of five new employee records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
4

R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Three of ten employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
One employee’s Michigan Department of Human Services
clearance was obtained more than 30 days prior to the
employee’s 7/11/18 date of hire.
A second employee’s Michigan Department of Human Services
clearance was obtained 15 days after the employee’s 11/13/17
date of hire.
A third employee’s annual Michigan Department of Human
Services clearance was obtained more than 60 days after the
employee’s annual clearance due date.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2017.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Two of ten employee records reviewed showed where the
employee was employed for over a year did not show
documentation of an annual performance evaluation.

The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Nothing this licensing reporting period.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.4113(i) Employee record
The agency is advised, from a best practice standard it may want to consider
completing an updated criminal record ICHATs for employees who have been
employed for numerous years. For instance, one employee’s record showed the
employee, identified as a youth specialist, was employed with the agency since 1995;
and the employee’s original ICHAT clearance nor a later one was not on file.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The corrective action plan related to the
agency’s 2017 Interim Inspection. During that Interim Inspection, the agency received
two citations under R400.4113 for Employee records pertaining to subrules (i) and(j).
It also received one citation under R400.4114 for Tuberculosis screening for
employees and volunteers. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action
plan, but it was not completely successful with that plan. The agency received two
repeat violations under R400.4113 for Employee records pertaining to subrules (i)
and(j). The number of records cited for compliance to subrule(i) which pertains to
6

obtaining Michigan Department of Human Services clearances deceased slightly this
inspection. It increased slightly related to compliance to subrule(j) that pertains to
written performance evaluations.
The agency’s placement of residents has been up and down this licensing period, but
it has had no significant programming changes. On the original date of the on-site
inspection, there were no residents in placement. The agency reported one resident
had discharged the day before, and other residents had discharged prior. A follow up
on-site visit was conducted on 9/4/18, at which time the agency had six residents in
care. At the time of the original on-site inspection the agency was awaiting word
related to the federal shelter contract. The agency anticipates a possible decrease in
monies granted to the program and or how the monies may be utilized to service
youths and their families.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
